title: Qatari Director Mohammed Al-Ibrahim on First Feature ‘Sa3ood Wainah?’: ‘I Wanted to Look Into Why People Decide to Lead Double Lives From Our Perspective’
description: It took Qatari director Mohammed Al-Ibrahim 15 years to make his first feature “Sa3ood Wainah?,” which, starting from its title, is a pretty unique
body:
It took Qatari director Mohammed Al-Ibrahim 15 years to make his first feature “Sa3ood Wainah?,” which, starting from its title, is a pretty unique film blending thriller, fantasy and magic realism elements, all imbued with a strong local flavor.

	Billed as the first “commercial” film to come out of Qatar, “Sa3ood Wainah?” – the title translates as “Where is Saoud?” – launched from the inaugural Doha Film Festival this week, where it was cheered by the home crowd. It’s produced by Katara Studios which is keen on fostering filmmaking and content production in the minuscule gas-rich Gulf nation.
	

	Set in a remote Qatari farmhouse, “Sa3ood Wainah?” turns on two brothers named Hamood and Sa3ood, who one night entertain their friends with a magic trick passed down by their late father. This leads to the disappearance of Sa3oud and the blurring of boundaries between illusion and reality.


	Katara Studios will be releasing the film theatrically in the Gulf region next year.

	Al-Ibrahim, who studied filmmaking at UC Irvine, started his career working at the Doha Film Institute, and has been cutting his teeth making lots of shorts and commercials. As current head of longform at Katara Studios, he directed the music video for the FIFA World Cup 2022 song “Arhbo” that got more than 100 million views on YouTube.

	Al-Ibrahim spoke to Variety in Doha about why it’s crucial that his feature debut be “a grassroots Qatari film.” 

	How did you come up with the concept, which is pretty innovative, especially for the region?

	I consume quite a bit of genre, and I feel like people here have a huge appetite for genre as well. So it’s only fair that we as Qataris or people in the Gulf region can have some sort of visual representation of ourselves in that light. That was the first thing. And then my colleague Jassim Abel, and I co-wrote the story. I wrote the screenplay, he co-wrote the treatment with me. We were having a lot of “what if?” discussions. Such as how can we make a movie that’s self-contained? We were discussing films such as [Sidney Lumet’s courtroom drama] “12 Angry Men” and other films that take place on one location. We started with the “what ifs?” And the one that stuck with us was: what if a magic trick were not something magic. What if it was real?
	

	It seems to me that you really wanted to make this film culturally specific. What were the elements from Qatari culture that you drew upon?

	Magic is part of our folklore. This goes back to the time of ancient Egypt. It’s there, though it’s not talked about very much. So I definitely wanted some of that. As far as themes go, from a modern perspective, I think in our identities, we sometimes tend to lead double lives. So I wanted that to be a part of the film as well. And I wanted to look into why people decide to lead double lives from our perspective. We’ve seen it in lots of films coming from the West, but I wanted to have a take on that from here.

	You cast all Qatari actors, which is an interesting choice since this is a commercial feature. Did you consider other options?

	I’ll be honest with you, there was that conversation in the beginning. We were wondering if we should have some talent from Saudi Arabia or from Kuwait. But then we quickly realized that we had to focus on our mission. And that mission is a grassroots Qatari film. A Qatari story told and performed by Qataris. Not only for me, but I think for Katara Studios as well, it’s very important that we let people know that: hey, we’re here; we exist. And we want you to see what we’re up to.

	The audience in Doha certainly seemed to enjoy it. How did it feel launching the flm at the inaugural Doha Film Festival amid a flurry of announcements from the nascent Film Committee  about ways in which Qatar is building a film industry?

	It makes me feel great. I feel like I’m getting involved. I mean it’s been a 15-year journey trying to make a feature film and to cement myself as a filmmaker. And I feel like I’m here in the right place at the right time. I feel like as a nation we are investing heavily in cinema as a cultural export. We realize the power of story and how it’s an extension of our identity, and an extension of diplomacy. The fact that the Qatar Film Committee is spearheading this is a testament to that.

	This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.



	

									Courtesy Katara Studios

schema.headline: Qatari Director Mohammed Al-Ibrahim on First Feature ‘Sa3ood Wainah?’: ‘I Wanted to Look Into Why People Decide to Lead Double Lives From Our Perspective’

title: Oscar Predictions: Best Director — Park Chan-wook Could Crash the Party as Ryan Coogler’s Historic Bid Gains Momentum
description:
Nov 27, 2025 10:05pm PT	
	

	
	Oscar Predictions: Best Director — Park Chan-wook Could Crash the Party as Ryan Coogler’s Historic Bid Gains Mo
body:
Nov 27, 2025 10:05pm PT	
	

	
	Oscar Predictions: Best Director — Park Chan-wook Could Crash the Party as Ryan Coogler’s Historic Bid Gains Momentum
	



			
			
	
						

									CJ ENM
	
					


							
		

	Variety Awards Circuit section is the home for all awards news and related content throughout the year, featuring the following: the official predictions for the upcoming Oscars, Emmys, Grammys and Tony Awards ceremonies, curated by Variety chief awards editor Clayton Davis. The prediction pages reflect the current standings in the race and do not reflect personal preferences for any individual contender. As other formal (and informal) polls suggest, competitions are fluid and subject to change based on buzz and events. Predictions are updated every Thursday.



	

									Warner Bros.
	



	Oscars Best Director Commentary (Updated Nov. 27, 2025): Park Chan-wook makes his first appearance in the projected best director lineup this season, signaling a meaningful shift in an already fluid race. His precision-crafted work on Neon’s “No Other Choice” has quietly built momentum across the fall festivals, winning audience awards, and as shown in the latest forecast, now stands shoulder to shoulder with some of the year’s most formidable contenders.

	Elsewhere in the field, Ryan Coogler’s “Sinners” continues to climb with purpose and resonance after its strong showing with Critics Choice’s shortlist announcement. The film’s blend of muscular storytelling and cultural urgency has made it one of the season’s most widely admired entries, keeping Coogler firmly entrenched among the top contenders. If the momentum holds, Coogler could make history as the first Black filmmaker to win the Oscar for best director — a barrier the Academy has yet to break in nearly 100 years. 

	With titles such as “One Battle After Another,” “Hamnet” and “Sentimental Value” continuing to secure industry admiration, the race remains competitive and incredibly unpredictable. As precursors begin to roll out next week and late-year screenings intensify, the field appears poised for further evolution.

	Next stop…the Gothams Awards in New York City, which will be handed out as James Cameron’s anticipated “Avatar: Fire and Ash” is premiering in L.A.

	Big week ahead.

	NOTE: All titles, release dates, studios and listed category classifications are subject to change.


			
			
			
										
					Image Credit: "Sentimental Value" (Courtesy of Cannes Film Festival)

title: Paramount+ Signs Marketing Deal With Arsenal Soccer Club After Winning U.K. Champions League Rights
description: A week after its landmark four-year, $1 billion-plus deal securing the rights to show Champion League matches in the U.K., Paramount+ has doubled-do
body:
A week after its landmark four-year, $1 billion-plus deal securing the rights to show Champion League matches in the U.K., Paramount+ has doubled-down on British soccer.

	The streamer has signed a partnership with Arsenal — currently sitting atop the U.K.’s Premier League — that it says will see the team’s “players, club legends and supporters come together to celebrate some of Paramount+’s iconic series.”


	Among those series mentioned are “Landman” and “MobLand,” with Paramount saying Arsenal will collaborate on social media campaigns and that Paramount+ branding will be featured inside the stadium, big screens, matchday programmes and other experiences and activations. 
	

	As part of the announcement, Paramount+ released a promotional video entitled “For the Love of the Team” narrated by Arsenal icon Thierry Henry, who currently works as a pundit for CBS Sports.

	“We’re beyond excited to unite Paramount+ and Arsenal– two global iconic brands with supporters that live and breathe passion,” said Marco Nobili, executive vice president and international general manager of Paramount+. “With hit series like ‘SpongeBob,’ ‘South Park,’ ‘Landman,’ ‘Yellowstone’ and more, we’re creating experiences that celebrate teamwork, elevate the game and connect supporters. This partnership brings the drama, comedy, and unforgettable moments of both worlds to life – on the pitch and beyond.”

	The moves come following the dramatic entering of Paramount into the U.K. soccer landscape after it won the auction to broadcast most Champions League matches from 2027 to 2031. The company beat current rights holders TNT with reported to be considerably higher than the $1.3 billion TNT paid.

schema.headline: Paramount+ Signs Marketing Deal With Arsenal Soccer Club After Winning U.K. Champions League Rights

title: Dhafer L’Abidine’s Thriller ‘Sophia’ Boarded by MAD World Ahead of Marrakech Film Festival Premiere (EXCLUSIVE)
description: MAD World, the Arab world’s leading international film sales agent, has picked up “Sophia,” directed by and starring Dhafer L’Abidine, who also star
body:
MAD World, the Arab world’s leading international film sales agent, has picked up “Sophia,” directed by and starring Dhafer L’Abidine, who also stars in “Palestine 36,” Palestine’s Oscar entry. “Sophia” has its world premiere on Tuesday at Marrakech Film Festival, where “Palestine 36” also screens.

	“Sophia,” which centers on a trip to reconnect a daughter with her roots gone wrong, also stars Jessica Brown Findlay (“Brave New World,” “Harlots,” “Downton Abbey”), Jonathan Hyde (“The Brutalist”), Kais Setti (“Tracing Addai,” “Haps”), Hiba Abouk (“The Prince”), and Maya Celine Gharbi.
	

	The film follows Emily, who – against the wishes of her father – travels from London to Tunisia in the hopes of reconnecting her daughter, Sophia, with her estranged husband. The unthinkable happens when Sophia disappears, and lies and deceit quickly ensnare the broken family. Emily’s world is flipped upside down as she races against time to find her daughter.


	L’Abidine, who was interviewed this week by Variety, said: “ ‘Sophia’ is a thriller with a heart. When I started working on it, I wanted to tell a human story, one that transcends geography and nationality, and speaks to audiences everywhere.”

	Alaa Karkouti and Maher Diab, co-founders of MAD World, said: “ ‘Sophia’ is a bold and raw take on the clash between the present and the past, the interplay of where we are now and where we come from, and the lengths we go to reconcile them so that we can walk toward the future unburdened. It is beautiful to watch, and we’re excited to bring it to the world.”
	

	The film brings together L’Abidine’s own production company, Double A Productions, with L’Abidine as the producer, and New Sparta Productions in a Tunisian-British co-production.

	Christopher Simon, the film’s co-producer, said, “Especially in times like these, telling stories that foster deeper understanding, empathy, and connection between our worlds feels more important than ever.”

	The film is lensed by Willie Nel, and edited by Hafedh Laaridhi, with Adel Ouni serving as the production designer, Moncef Taleb on sound, and Selim Arjoun handling the score.

	L’Abidine’s career spans British television, international cinema, and major productions across the Arab world. A graduate of the Birmingham School of Speech and Drama, he began his screen journey in the U.K. with shows such as “Dream Team” and “Spooks.” He went on to appear in high-profile films like “Children of Men” and “Sex and the City 2,” and on TV series including “The Looming Tower” and “The Eddy.” In the Arab region, he became a household name through series such as “Maktoub,” “Halawat El Donia” and “Arous Beirut.”

	As a director, L’Abidine made his feature debut with “Ghodwa,” which he co-wrote, directed, starred in, and produced through Double A Productions. The film was shortlisted for the Golden Globe Awards and won the FIPRESCI Prize at the Cairo Film Festival. His second feature, “To My Son,” earned best film and a special mention for screenwriting at the Hollywood Arab Film Festival.

schema.headline: Dhafer L’Abidine’s Thriller ‘Sophia’ Boarded by MAD World Ahead of Marrakech Film Festival Premiere (EXCLUSIVE)

title: ‘Behind the Palm Trees’ Director Meryem Benm’barek Refuses to Compromise: ‘I Needed to Maintain Absolute Creative Freedom’
description: “Behind the Palm Trees” director Meryem Benm’barek is navigating a swirl of emotions as her film prepares for its world premiere at the Marrakech Fi
body:
“Behind the Palm Trees” director Meryem Benm’barek is navigating a swirl of emotions as her film prepares for its world premiere at the Marrakech Film Festival. 

	On the one hand, the Moroccan auteur — whose feature debut “Sofia” was acclaimed in Un Certain Regard in 2018 — is deeply moved to unveil her latest work in her home country.

	“I know my film will be received here on a very deep level,” she tells Variety. 


	At the same time, that joy crowns years of struggle to bring the project to life. “Making this film was very hard,” she says. “For seven years I went through moments of real despair, but I never gave up. Above all, I held onto my vision, even though the process was extraordinarily complicated and the film was made under very difficult economic conditions.”
	

	Unlike her 2018 breakout, “Behind the Palm Trees” did not benefit from key public mechanisms that often prove essential for projects of this scale. The absence of French institutional support was particularly striking for a film featuring well-known performers such as Carole Bouquet and Olivier Rabourdin. 



	

					Carole Bouquet in ‘Behind the Palm Trees’
	



	“It says something about how difficult it is for France today to look at the consequences of its colonial past straight in the eye in order to repair certain things,” Benm’barek reflects. “It’s also hard, I think, for many French people to accept the position they still occupy in many countries, particularly in Africa.”

	Instead, the film came together through a patchwork of international and local solidarity. “The film existed thanks to the support of England, Morocco and Belgium, but also thanks to a collective momentum from the Tangier community, which fully rallied around the project,” she says. “I’m lucky to have many friends in Tangier who helped me. It truly became a collective effort for the film to exist. We lacked money, but we didn’t give up.”
	

	Crucially, she adds, her creative autonomy was never compromised. “My producers never once asked me to make artistic concessions [especially around the frank depictions of sexuality, which made the project challenging in certain territories],” she continues. “Unfortunately, given the state of the film industry today, directors often have to compromise — sometimes even during the writing process. But I can say that this film fully reflects my vision of the world. Every line of dialogue, every shot, every camera move was thought through and carefully chosen. That makes all the difference; I left absolutely nothing to chance.”

	Indeed, it would be nearly impossible to erase all traces of sexuality from an intimate thriller centered on a young man from Tangier torn between two starkly different romantic partners. While young contractor Mehdi (Driss Ramdi) is already half-engaged to Selma (Nadia Kounda), a socially reserved bakery worker, he soon finds himself drawn to the sexually liberated Marie (Sara Giraudeau) — an affluent Frenchwoman who begins as a client before becoming his lover and social benefactor, fueling his fantasies of upward mobility and a different life.



	

					Driss Ramdi and Sara Giraudeau 
	



	“I needed to maintain absolute creative freedom,” Benm’barek explains. “Marie gives access to her body — and it was important that this could be seen, since the story is experienced through Mehdi’s gaze. Selma, by contrast, is defined by modesty; she doesn’t reveal herself and denies access to her body. The intimate scenes therefore required a different visual language. These were deliberate choices, reflecting my artistic vision and the direction I wanted for the film, even if they may not resonate with everyone.” 

	Films like “Dirty Dancing” and “Titanic” resonated with Benm’barek as she developed her latest feature, inspiring her to blend sharp social commentary with a compelling, accessible narrative. 

	“‘Dirty Dancing’ was so far ahead of its time,” she says. “It deals with abortion, class divisions, the emancipation of a young girl becoming a woman and freeing herself from her father. [And ‘Titanic,’ like many films]  follow a character moving from one social class to another.” 

	“I was raised on 90s thrillers and those slightly cheesy TV movies on Saturday nights,” she continues. “I make the kinds of films I would’ve loved as a spectator. I don’t think we should overthink everything. Pleasure has to stay at the center, because making films is hard — and it’s only getting harder.”
	

	“Ours is a job full of doubt, where nothing is ever really easy,” she says. “So it’s important to hold on to that place of pleasure, to remember what made us want to create films in the first place. We were spectators before anything else, and we were moved by films. That sense of pleasure is essential — otherwise, it just becomes too hard to keep going.”



	

					Driss Ramdi and Nadia Kounda

schema.headline: ‘Behind the Palm Trees’ Director Meryem Benm’barek Refuses to Compromise: ‘I Needed to Maintain Absolute Creative Freedom’

title: Indonesia-France Film Lab Returns to JAFF Market in Yogyakarta
description: The French Embassy’s Institut français d’Indonésie (IFI) has launched the second edition of the Indonesia-France Film Lab, running Nov. 27 through D
body:
The French Embassy’s Institut français d’Indonésie (IFI) has launched the second edition of the Indonesia-France Film Lab, running Nov. 27 through Dec. 1 in Yogyakarta.

	The initiative, presented as Indonesia France Film Lab X MTN Lab, takes place within the JAFF Market framework during the 27th Festival Sinema Prancis. The program is partnering with Indonesia’s Ministry of Culture under the Manajemen Talenta Nasional program, the Association of Indonesian Film Producers (APROFI), and the Asian Film Alliance Network (AFAN).
	

	Six emerging Indonesian director-producer teams developing their first or second features have been selected for the lab, which receives additional support from France’s Centre national du cinéma et de l’image animée (CNC) and La Fémis film school.


	The program comprises two components: a scriptwriting workshop led by French script consultant Eric Collins from La Fémis, and an industry lab featuring five French film professionals. The roster includes Thomas Rosso, general coordinator of La Semaine de la Critique at Cannes; producers Xénia Maingot (Eaux Vives Productions), Jérémie Palanque (Woooz Pictures), Christophe Bruncher (Ici et Là Productions), and Marine Arrighi de Casanova (Apsara Films).

	Selected projects include M. Dhaffa Attoriq’s “A Mother’s Niqab” from 3 Pulau Pictures, Maarij Reka’s “The Boy with His Mother’s Statue” from Veneirs Films, and Daphne’s “The First Journey of Grief” from Aztec Production. Also chosen were Devina Sofiyanti’s “The Heirlooms” from Qun Films, Fanny Chotimah’s “The Last Dance” from Kembang Gula, and Trinisha Aksa’s “What to Wear for My Own Funeral” from Ujung Pandang Studios.
	

	Looking ahead to 2026, several lab projects will be presented at a CNC-organized co-production meeting featuring Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam and the Philippines, with 15 selected projects total. Michel Plazanet, deputy director for European and international affairs at CNC, is participating in this year’s lab, following CNC president Gaëtan Bruel’s Jakarta visit in July.

	La Semaine de la Critique has also announced Next Step Studio Indonesia, a short film co-creation program for emerging Indonesian directors launching in May 2026.

	“Building on the joint cultural strategy between France and Indonesia adopted by our two Presidents last May in Borobudur, the Indonesia-France Film Lab highlights our joint commitment to supporting emerging Indonesian filmmakers, who represent the next generation of talents – ‘the Indonesian new wave.’ It is co-organised and co-funded by the Indonesian ministry of Culture, the French Embassy and Aprofi. With its strengthened curriculum and the strong institutional support of the French National Center for Cinema (CNC) and La Fémis, considered as one of the world’s leading film schools, the Lab has become an important platform for fostering new co-production opportunities,” said Fabien Penone, French ambassador to Indonesia, Timor Leste and ASEAN.

	“For JAFF Market, the presence of this lab reinforces our mission to become a true meeting point between Indonesian talent and the global film community. It deepens our role as a catalyst – connecting filmmakers, producers, and institutions while creating long-term creative pathways. I see the Indonesia-France Film Lab lab as one of the most strategic collaborations we’ve built. It provides Indonesian filmmakers with direct, consistent access to mentors, methodologies, and artistic approaches that have shaped some of the world’s most influential cinema,” added Gita Fara, head of program for JAFF Market.

	“The Indonesia-France Lab is a wonderful platform that offers Indonesian filmmakers the opportunity to develop strong scripts, fostering potential for international collaboration and bringing Indonesian projects to the global market,” said Edwin Nazir, chairman of APROFI.

	Selected Projects:

	“A Mother’s Niqab” Director: M. Dhaffa Attoriq Producer: Stephanie Ong Production Company: 3 Pulau Pictures
	

	“The Boy With His Mother’s Statue” Director: Maarij Reka Producer: Mozad Irvany Production Company: Veneirs Films

	“The First Journey of Grief” Director: Daphne Producer: Alvin Wijaya Production Company: Aztec Production

	“The Heirlooms” Writer/Director: Devina Sofiyanti Co-Writer: Ahmad Yuniardi Producer: Giovanni Rahmadeva Production Company: Qun Films

	“The Last Dance” Director/Producer: Fanny Chotimah Writer: Adimas Immanuel Production Company: Kembang Gula

	“What to Wear for My Own Funeral” Director: Trinisha Aksa Writer: Haediqal Pawennei Producers: Haediqal Pawennei, Rania Sulfa Production Company: Ujung Pandang Studios

schema.headline: Indonesia-France Film Lab Returns to JAFF Market in Yogyakarta

title: Kajol, Twinkle Khanna’s ‘Two Much’ Becomes Prime Video India’s Most-Watched Unscripted Series (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Prime Video‘s celebrity talk show “Two Much with Kajol and Twinkle,” hosted by Bollywood star Kajol and author-producer Twinkle Khanna, has emerged
body:
Prime Video‘s celebrity talk show “Two Much with Kajol and Twinkle,” hosted by Bollywood star Kajol and author-producer Twinkle Khanna, has emerged as the platform’s most successful unscripted series in India, reaching viewers across more than 93% of the country’s postal codes.

	The first season of the Banijay Asia-produced series featured an array of major Bollywood personalities, including Salman Khan, Aamir Khan, Akshay Kumar, Saif Ali Khan, Alia Bhatt, Kriti Sanon, Varun Dhawan and Karan Johar, concluding with an episode featuring cricket World Cup champions Jemimah Rodrigues and Shafali Verma. 
	

	“The overwhelming response to ‘Two Much with Kajol and Twinkle‘ is a testament to the refreshing new perspective it has brought to talk shows, making it Prime Video’s most-watched unscripted series to date,” said Nikhil Madhok, director and head of originals at Prime Video India. “What sets the show apart is our phenomenal pairing of hosts, who have been unabashedly candid, unapologetic and unfiltered.”


	Mrinalini Jain, group chief development officer at Banijay Asia and Endemol Shine India, said the show “became a phenomenon because it delivered the one thing audiences crave today – unfiltered and witty conversations.”

	“In essence, ‘Two Much with Kajol and Twinkle’ is about friends coming together in a safe space that feels like home where they can be their natural selves, speak their minds, and reminisce about stories that would otherwise live only in their memories,” Khanna said.

	Kajol added: “Sitting on the other side of the couch for ‘Two Much’ felt wonderfully refreshing, especially with Twinkle as the co-host, who is genuinely one of the funniest and sharpest women I know.”

schema.headline: Kajol, Twinkle Khanna’s ‘Two Much’ Becomes Prime Video India’s Most-Watched Unscripted Series (EXCLUSIVE)

title: ‘Zootopia 2’ Smashes China Box Office Records With $34 Million Opening Day
description: Disney’s “Zootopia 2” has roared to a phenomenal start in China, setting multiple box office records and signaling strong momentum for the animated
body:
Disney’s “Zootopia 2” has roared to a phenomenal start in China, setting multiple box office records and signaling strong momentum for the animated sequel’s global rollout.

	The film, a buddy cop movie with anthropomorphic animals as the bickering partners, earned $34 million on its opening day in China, per numbers from Disney, marking the highest opening day and highest single-day box office ever for a U.S. animated film in the territory. The performance also represents the strongest opening day for any U.S. title in China since May 2021.
	

	The opening day ranks as the 10th highest opening day of all time for a U.S. release in China overall. Social scores have been excellent, with the film earning a 9.7 rating on Maoyan, comparing favorably to the original “Zootopia” (9.5), “Inside Out 2” (9.1) and “Ralph Breaks The Internet” (8.8).


	Globally, “Zootopia 2” has accumulated an estimated $81.1 million, with $39.5 million from domestic markets and $41.6 million from international territories. The film opened Wednesday in 17 markets, including France, Germany, Italy, China and Korea.

	The domestic opening day performance marked the second highest Wednesday before Thanksgiving of all time, behind only “Moana 2” ($57.9 million), and the third highest domestic opening day for a Walt Disney Animation Studios animated title behind “Moana 2” and “Frozen 2” ($42.2 million).

	Audience reception has been strong across the board, with the film earning 95% from Rotten Tomatoes audiences, an “A” CinemaScore and 4.5 out of 5 stars from PostTrak.

	Beyond China, “Zootopia 2” secured the number one position in most international markets. In Korea, the opening day marked the fifth highest animated opening day of all time and the second highest opening day among all Walt Disney Animation Studios films behind “Frozen 2.” The film earned $1.7 million in the territory, with social scores of 9.30 on Naver and 98% on CGV.
	

	In Europe, the film achieved the highest MPA animated opening day of 2025 in France, Germany and Italy, earning $2.4 million, $700,000 and $600,000 respectively.

	The sequel continues its rollout this weekend and will be open in approximately 93% of the international landscape by Sunday, including all markets except Japan, which opens the following weekend.

schema.headline: ‘Zootopia 2’ Smashes China Box Office Records With $34 Million Opening Day

title: ‘Cold War’ Star Joanna Kulig Discusses Nora Jaenicke’s ‘Isola,’ and Singing in Paweł Pawlikowski’s Next Film
description: It has been a while since the “Cold War” craze and its three Academy Award nominations, but its Polish breakout star Joanna Kulig will soon reunite
body:
It has been a while since the “Cold War” craze and its three Academy Award nominations, but its Polish breakout star Joanna Kulig will soon reunite with director Paweł Pawlikowski once again. 

	“I’m singing in his next film,” she says. In the anticipated drama, starring Sandra Hüller, known as “1949/Vaterland,” Pawlikowski will explore the life of Thomas and Erika Mann in post-war Germany. 


	“This will be our fourth collaboration. I’m so proud this film exists, especially in these difficult times post-pandemic and strikes. Cinema is still fighting back.”
	

	Kulig’s extensive run on the awards circuit – which coincided with her becoming a mother to a baby boy – raised her international profile, but she resisted the pressure to pursue solely U.S. projects. At Torino Film Festival, she’s presenting Nora Jaenicke’s psychological thriller “Isola.”

	“Right after ‘Cold War,’ things got a bit crazy. I know some people expected me to stay [in the U.S.], but one reason why I’ve always admired Paweł Pawlikowski is that he has his own, very specific way of developing films. You have to find something that works for you and brings you peace and joy, instead of listening to all these external voices,” she notes. 

	“’Cold War’ opened me up to multiculturalism and so many new opportunities. They probably wouldn’t have happened if it wasn’t for that film. However, I also want to have a family life, and I think I’ve achieved that balance right now.” 

	Following Berlinale opener “She Came to Me” and Apple TV+ miniseries “Masters of the Air,” she’s focusing on European productions. 
	

	“They’re much closer. With ‘Isola,’ I could do so many things in Warsaw. I’ve always wanted to have a base, a permanent place of my own, and I’ve managed to build it now. It’s funny, because people in Poland keep asking me: ‘Oh, so you’re back?’ I never left!,” she laughs.

	“We Poles are incredibly open to learning new languages and entering new working environments. There’s still this thought at the back of our head that we’re not good enough, which is a remnant from the communist era. My generation believed that the West was better somehow, but it’s time we learnt to appreciate ourselves.” 

	Before Pawlikowski’s latest, Kulig gets to sing in Jaenicke’s film as well, where she plays the much younger wife of a dying man, also named Joanna. Stuck on a remote island, she’s happy to welcome new caretaker Ada (Fanny Ardant), but Ada’s affection soon turns into obsession. 

	Jaenicke explains: “It was a Sicilian song because at first, the film was supposed to be set in Stromboli. We needed a brief moment when they could connect. They don’t need words; they just look at each other. This song really moves Ada and she gets to see a wild side of Joanna that wants to break free from being just a wife.” 

	“When I got to know Joanna [Kulig], her character rewrote itself, in a way. She has this intense gaze and she can look so angelic, but then there’s a shift. I saw a little bit of a devil in her too.”

	“Isola” is produced by Manish Mundra, Ariens Damsi and Jaenicke for Drishyam Films International and Eliofilm. 

	Jaenicke, who is making her feature debut, also wanted to show Ardant in a different light. “We haven’t really seen her in a role like this before. Fanny said she liked Ada because ‘she isn’t likeable.’” 

	Then again, nobody is likeable in “Isola.” According to co-star Marco Rossetti, playing Joanna’s love interest, Jaenicke’s film has a noir feel, with all the characters inflicting psychological and physical violence on each other and ultimately being united by their “ambiguous morality.”

	“It’s almost like some archetypal story,” the director sums up.

	“Ada comes into Joanna’s life when she’s already thinking about breaking free from her pattern: she always ends up with people who try to control her. In a way, it’s a feminist story. But then it’s another woman who suddenly dominates her, just like a man.”

schema.headline: ‘Cold War’ Star Joanna Kulig Discusses Nora Jaenicke’s ‘Isola,’ and Singing in Paweł Pawlikowski’s Next Film

title: Retailers Unveil Black Friday TV Deals, With Sony, Samsung and LG Models Up to 57% Off
description:
Nov 27, 2025 10:23pm PT	
	

	
		Retailers Unveil Black Friday TV Deals, With Sony, Samsung and LG Models Up to 57% Off
	

	Whether y
body:
Nov 27, 2025 10:23pm PT	
	

	
		Retailers Unveil Black Friday TV Deals, With Sony, Samsung and LG Models Up to 57% Off
	

	Whether you're a film buff looking to upgrade your home theater, or a sports fan who needs a TV with less lag and blur, here are the Black Friday TV deals worth shopping this year
	
			


			
			
	

									AFP via Getty Images
	

		
	
				
	If you purchase an independently reviewed product or service through a link on our website, Variety may receive an affiliate commission.

	Black Friday is one of the best times of the year to snag big ticket items at discounted prices. Case in point: name brand television sets are down to their lowest prices of the year this weekend, with brands like Samsung, LG and TCL all offering big-screen TVs for up to 57% off. These aren’t just close-out or discontinued models either — many of them are brand new 2025 units that are marked down on sale for the first time (prices are even cheaper than Prime Day).


	And while snagging a Black Friday TV deal used to mean lining up at wee hours of the morning to score a doorbuster deal in person, you can now find the same sales online with just the click of a button. 

	We’ve rounded up some of the best Black Friday TV sales from Amazon, Best Buy and Walmart to shop now. Whether you’re a film buff looking to upgrade your home theater experience, or a sports fan who wants a better (and bigger) TV with less lag and blur, here are the Black Friday TV deals worth picking up this year.

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					TCL 55″ Class F35 Series 4K UHD HDR LED Smart Fire TV		

	
		This 55-inch TCL TV is already an excellent deal at its regular $329 price point, but Best Buy’s Black Friday sale has it marked down by almost 50% off. The smart TV pairs easily with all your favorite streaming apps, with content in 4K UHD resolution. Best Buy lets you order a TV online for same-day store pickup or you can select free home delivery. This is a Best Buy Black Friday doorbuster deal and it’s selling fast so we recommend adding it to your cart now.	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					INSIGNIA 50″ Class F50 Series LED 4K UHD Smart Fire TV		

	
		Amazon’s Insignia Fire TV is a great entry-level Smart TV, with a crisp 4K display and an included remote that includes voice control functions, so you can ask Alexa to change channels, adjust settings and more. The 50-inch size makes this ideal for a bedroom, work space or small apartment.	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					Roku 50″ Select Series 4K HDR TV		

	
		Roku TVs are one of the best values in home entertainment, with more than 400 free television channels built into your Roku ecosystem, so you can always find a TV show or movie to watch without needing a streaming service or cable. Features-wise, this 50-inch TV features 4K picture quality and HDR color for brighter, more vivid images on screen. 	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					INSIGNIA 65″ Class F50 Series LED 4K UHD Smart Fire TV		

	
		A 65-inch TV is the new norm when it comes to screen size, and Amazon’s Black Friday deals let you snag a 65-inch 4K set for under $300. This is one of the best deals we’re seeing this year and it’s sure to sell out fast, so we suggest picking it up while the deal is still live.	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					Sony BRAVIA 2 43″ 4K Ultra HD LED Smart TV		

	
		Sony TVs almost never go on sale and this Black Friday deal gets you one of the brand’s signature BRAVIA sets for just $368. This 43-inch TV features a brilliant 4K LED screen with cinema-style Dolby Atmos sound and a processor that automatically upscales content for clarity and contrasts. The TV has built-in support for Apple AirPlay 2 and Google Cast, and it’s great for gaming too, with BRAVIA-exclusive features like Auto HDR Tone Mapping and Auto Genre Picture Mode that optimizes picture quality and reduces motion blur.	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					Samsung 75” Class Q6F Series QLED 4K UHD TV		

	
		Best Buy’s Black Friday TV deals include this bestselling Samsung model discounted to just $599. Get 4K resolution on a big 75-inch display, with Samsung’s smart processor automatically optimizing audio and picture quality. Nano-sized “Quantum Dots,” meantime, work together to crate “100% color volume” on screen, no matter how bright or dark your room — or the scene — is. Samsung’s Bixby voice assistant is built-in, allowing you to use your voice to launch apps, control settings, use the TV as a smart home hub and more.	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					TCL 75″ Class QM6K Series 4K HDR TV		

	
		I’ve used a TCL TV for years and it’s one of the best everyday picks for watching live sports, TV shows, movies or gaming. Picture quality is consistent with high brightness and sharp contrasts, and the Dolby Atmos audio (via an ONKYO 2.1 speaker system with built-in subwoofer) is surprisingly loud and immersive. This Black Friday deal gets you a 75-inch set with TCL’s QD-Mini LED technology that delivers more than a billion colors on screen for better image accuracy. With built-in Google TV and an included voice remote, this is a TV that’s sure to deliver on all fronts.	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					LG 75″ Class QNED evo AI Mini LED 4K Smart TV		

	
		LG is one of the best TV brands on the market today and Amazon’s Black Friday sale gives you a chance to snag a 75-inch LG QNED TV for under $900. The picture quality in an LG set is instantly noticeable when compared to cheaper brands and models, with incredibly evocative images that are less muddled and less flat. As one reviewer notes, this TV offers, “Fabulous picture, so clear and lifelike,” while another notes that he his Xbox and PS5 games look more realistic on the screen, saying, “If you are a gamer you will not be disappointed.”	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					Samsung 65″ Class QLED 4K LS03D The Frame Series Quantum HDR Smart TV		

	
		Ask anyone who owns a Samsung Frame TV and they’ll immediately tell you how much they love it (this author included). The slim and minimalist unit sits discreetly on your wall and doubles as artwork when you’re not using it to watch TV. The anti-reflection display gives off a matte finish to eliminate annoying glare during the daytime, while Samsung’s “One Connect Box” eliminates wire clutter by powering the TV and connecting streaming and gaming devices with a single cable. A bonus: access thousands of hours of content with Samsung TV Plus’ more than 400 free channels. Get the Samsung Frame on sale for under $1,000 for a limited time with this Black Friday deal.	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					Hisense 98″ Class QD5 Series QLED 4K UHD Smart Google TV		

	
		The best Black Friday TV deal we’re seeing is for this massive 98-inch Hisense unit, on sale for 57% off. Getting a 98-inch TV for under $1,000 is virtually unheard of, especially from a trusted brand like Hisense. This one has all the bells and whistles you’d want in a big-screen TV, like a QLED display, Dolby Vision HDR imaging and Dolby Atmos sound, and a 4K upscaler that uses AI to enhance low-resolution content to as close to 4K quality as possible.	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					Sony 85″ Class 4K Ultra HD BRAVIA 3 LED Smart TV		

	
		Another Sony Black Friday TV deal gets you this 85-inch model for its lowest price of the year. The BRAVIA 3 unit is one of the most popular Sony sets online, with crystal clear images even in sunlight and a slim and sleek look. This is also one of the best-reviewed units online, with one Amazon reviewer praising its “Spectacular picture with 4K and HDR,” while another adds that, “We don’t need a soundbar since it sounds pretty good [on its own].”	
		
	

		

						
			
	

	
					
		

					LG 65″ Class OLED evo AI 4K Smart TV		

	
		Many reviewers and TV viewers alike swear by an OLED set, and LG makes one of the best OLED TVs available today. This 65-inch set promises “perfect blacks” and “perfect colors,” with incredibly realistic images no matter the room setup or lighting. LG’s intelligent AI automatically enhances depth, color and clarity while upscaling content to near-4K quality. A built-in “Filmmaker Mode,” meantime, turns off any post-processing effects to display the movie with the original aspect ratios and colors — I.e. as close as possible to how the filmmaker intended.	
		
	

		

			
			
			
			
	

	
					
		

					LG 100″ QNED evo AI Mini LED 4K UHD TV		

	
		And if you really want to go big, Walmart has this soaring 100-inch LG TV on sale for under $3,000 for Black Friday. Transform your home theater experience into a cinema-style experience with this giant 4K TV, which features HDR10 PRO picture quality and loud, immersive sound from the built-in speakers (though we recommend adding a sound bar or sound system to really turn it up). If you’re hosting movie night or a sports viewing party, this is the TV for you.	
		
	


	
		More from Variety
	
	
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
			
	
			
		

		

	
		More From Our Brands
	
	
		

			
	
			
			

	Rolling Stone

					Post Malone Electrifies Cowboys-Chiefs Thanksgiving Game With Halftime Show		

					
				
			
			
	
			
	
		
			
	
			
			

	Robb Report

					Taste Test: Heaven Hill’s New Limited-Edition Bourbon Is One of the Best of the Year		

					
				
			
			
	
			
	
		
			
	
			
			

	Sportico

					Dundon Ordered to Pay $1 in AAF Football League Bankruptcy Case		

					
				
			
			
	
			
	
		
			
	
			
			

	WWD

					Harrods Links With Rolex on Space for Pre-owned Watches Online and at the Knightsbridge Store

schema.headline: Retailers Unveil Black Friday TV Deals, With Sony, Samsung and LG Models Up to 57% Off

title: Kathy Ireland Launches Commercial Fishing Career
description:
Kathy Ireland
                          What a Catch!!!
                          Mogul Picks Up
body:
Kathy Ireland
                          What a Catch!!!
                          Mogul Picks Up Commercial Fishing
                      
                  
                        Published November 27, 2025 12:00 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
        
                    
                  
      
    
          Model-turned-mogul Kathy Ireland is making waves in a new arena -- commercial fishing --and she dished to TMZ about the sweet reason for the leap.
      
    
          Kathy said her husband of 37 years, Dr. Greg Olsen, has been commercial fishing for the last 20 years, and it's been a wonderful way to experience his passion.
      
    
          She explained, "Some people golf ... I commercial fish."
      

          And it just so happens, some of the skills may be transferable. According to Kathy, there are skills she's picked up in business that she's found crucial to success in fishing as well.
      
    
      
      Though I love working with my husband on the most beautiful ocean, as I’m filling bait jars with warm squishy mackerel, this is the verse that fills my heart!“I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.”Philippians 4:13 pic.twitter.com/l3ietPGyBz— kathy ireland (@kathyireland) October 31, 2025
              @kathyireland
          
  
    
          For one thing, you have to watch out for sharks in both. But you also have to be adaptable.
      
    
          She said, "You have to be able to pivot in business, and when you're heading out to sea and the weather is dynamic, you have to be prepared."
      
    
          Kathy shocked us when she revealed she and her husband man their vessel themselves -- just the 2 of them! While challenging, it's apparently not as difficult as some have assumed.
      
    
          In the spirit of the holidays, Harvey Levin gave Kathy a gift, pitching a new name for her burgeoning business ... watch the full video to hear it. Kathy laughed and thanked Harvey for the free idea.
      
    
          "I will ponder that," she said. We'll have to wait and see ...
      
      
              
            
              Related articles
            
        
              
          
                          
                Kathy Ireland
              
                          
                Money
              
                          
                Exclusive
              
                          
                Fairly Legal

schema.headline: Kathy Ireland Launches Commercial Fishing Career

title: Donald Trump Confirms One National Guard Member Is Dead After D.C. Shooting
description:
Washington, D.C. Shooting
                          One National Guard Member Dead
body:
Washington, D.C. Shooting
                          One National Guard Member Dead
                      
                  
                        Published November 27, 2025 4:27 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
          Tragic news out of D.C. -- one of the two National Guard members shot by Rahmanullah Lakanwal near the White House on Wednesday has died, President Trump confirmed Thursday.
      
    
          Trump, in his first live remarks since the shooting, said, "Sarah Beckstrom of West Virginia, highly respected, young, magnificent person... she’s just passed away. She’s no longer with us." Beckstrom was only 20 years old.
      
    
      
      .@POTUS announces that U.S. Army Specialist Sarah Beckstrom of Summersville, West Virginia, one of the National Guardsmen savagely attacked yesterday in Washington, D.C., has just passed away.May God be with her family 🙏 pic.twitter.com/BEbAOxmJme— Rapid Response 47 (@RapidResponse47) November 27, 2025
              @RapidResponse47
          
  

          The second Guard member, Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe, 24, is still in critical condition and fighting for his life, according to Trump.
      
    
          The FBI, U.S. Attorney's office, and the National Guard ID’d the shooter as 29-year-old Afghan national Lakanwal.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Social media footage showed the gunman being taken into custody on a D.C. street… with the two wounded National Guard members lying on the ground nearby.
      
    
      
      Video captures the moments immediately after the National Guard shooting in DC, including the alleged suspect being apprehended. pic.twitter.com/Hsj5aCDUfd
              @Breaking911
          
  
    
          No word yet on a motive -- authorities still aren’t saying what triggered the attack.
      
    
          With one Guard member now succumbing to her injuries, Lakanwal will face first-degree murder charges.

schema.headline: Donald Trump Confirms One National Guard Member Is Dead After D.C. Shooting

title: TikTok Star Marquay The Goat’s Death Tied to Prior Car Accident, Officials Say
description:
TikTok Star Marquay The Goat
                          TRAGIC DEATH TIED TO PRIOR CAR ACCIDENT
body:
TikTok Star Marquay The Goat
                          TRAGIC DEATH TIED TO PRIOR CAR ACCIDENT
                          ... According to County Coroner
                      
                  
                        Published November 27, 2025 12:25 PM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated November 27, 2025 1:01 PM PST
                                    
      
    
      
        
                    
                  
      
                    TikTok / @marquaythegoat
          
    
          TikTok star Marquay The Goat's sudden death is now believed to be connected to a serious car accident he was involved in just a couple weeks ago ... according to the county coroner.
      
    
          Buddy Bryan, the Muscogee County Coroner, tells TMZ ... Marquay Collins -- the TikToker's real name -- was pronounced dead at his home on Wednesday.
      
    
          However ... Bryan says Marquay was in a car crash on November 7th and was taken to the hospital, where he was evaluated and released the same day. After returning home, he began complaining of headaches, along with neck, shoulder and spine pain.
      

      
        
              
    
    
          Bryan also says Marquay told his brother he was experiencing shortness of breath and headaches before his death.
      
    
          While Marquay's case has formally been ruled undetermined ... Bryan believes Marquay's death is accident-related.
      
    
          In fact, Marquay documented his injuries on TikTok. In a video posted November 7th, he's seen on the side of a road in Atlanta with an ice pack pressed to his head -- claiming a Tesla rammed into the back of his car.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          The damage looks serious ... Marquay's bumper is crushed, and the Tesla is loaded onto a tow truck.
      
    
          Marquay says "my head is literally killing me right now," adding that his head is "banging" and "throbbing so hard."
      
    
          Moving forward ... we're told Marquay's body will be transported to the Georgia Bureau of Investigations for an autopsy. The case is still under investigation.

title: Megan Fox & Machine Gun Kelly Enjoy Outing At L.A. Zoo With Baby Daughter Saga
description:
Megan & MGK
                          Holiday Reunion For Baby Saga!!!
body:
Megan & MGK
                          Holiday Reunion For Baby Saga!!!
                      
                  
                        Published November 27, 2025 1:00 PM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated November 27, 2025 2:40 PM PST
                                    
      
    
      
        
                    
                  
      
                    BACKGRID
          
    
          Megan Fox and Machine Gun Kelly are in full holiday truce mode -- teaming up for some cozy family time with their little one ... proving these exes still roll as a unit when it counts.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The pair was spotted wandering through the dazzling L.A. Zoo Lights Wednesday, taking in all the glowing displays -- and MGK was carrying their baby girl, Saga Blade Fox-Baker, in a chest carrier like a total doting papa.
      
    
          Megan looked just as upbeat, strolling beside him with the pram -- giving full picture-perfect fam vibes as they stopped for pics and snapped selfies under those neon wings.
      

                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          And LBR ... there’s always been a spark between these two. MGK even recently claimed it was the evil eye that tore them apart last year -- with their baby girl arriving months later in March.
      
    
          But for now, it ain’t about the drama -- it’s all holiday cheer for little Saga!
